pros: Being able to impact the lives of girls and make connections in the community can be very rewarding.
cons: Local affiliates are left to fend for themselves without much support, guidance, or training from Girls Inc. National. Funding often depends on satisfying requirements of a corporate sponsor who has no knowledge of youth development. So the focus goes to satisfying sponsors who want to “feel good” about the work we do. The disconnect can limit programming and cause staff to plan for what they want instead of what participants need most. Also the lack of training for staff is disheartening. There’s a toxic underlying current of “ figure it out” that leaves staff burned out and almost forced to quit if you want some form of sanity.

pros: Free food sometimes. Woohoo? Talking with staff about how much things are unfair and you may get a sense of community from feeling supported with a lot of others who feel the same.
cons: Treat their employees horrible. Definitely about protecting their higher ups and folks in high up position can never be wrong even when they’re wrong. Overworked. Poor pay. You try to vouch and say you need to self care more they shift the language to you don’t like your job. Lots of anti blackness and protecting of. A certain class. Will have lower level staff do the dirty work.

job_title: Program Instructor in Winter Haven, FL
pros: The work and the community were the only reason any of the staff stayed
cons: Executive was hoarding supplies and money from the service population, lied directly to employees, did not communicate and had no idea how to lead. A previously fired social worker does not a leader make. She referred to her personal family to make organizational decisions and tolerated disrespect from her subordinates. No child, parent or staff --even board members respect them. Never gave praise, motivation or salary increases. Deserves to be let go at best, and sued at worst.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Worked with some of the most incredible students. The majority of my colleagues were great as well.
cons: Problematic white exec who would continuously compare her summer tan to the natural brown skin tone of the Black and Latina employees or refer to herself as a "woman of color" because of her summer tan. Some of my colleagues were not as committed to the girls as they should've been and were sadly just there to collect a check. The headquarters receives gifts and donations for staff but instead use it for themselves. The onsite staff was incredibly underpaid and very little appreciation was shown for quality employees who were on the frontlines.

pros: WOC- this isn't the unproblematic nonprofit safe haven you're hoping for.
cons:
What Girls Inc. stands for and what I experienced from my ex-boss don't align. My ex-boss was temperamental, rude, and has made a couple ignorant comments that I can't forgive. It was draining being the only black employee. The cultural insensitivity I experienced and witnessed was discouraging. The emotional labor was almost unbearable. 

During one of our last convos, my ex-boss regurgitated a sloppily veiled microaggression in which I was the aggressive "angry black woman" and she was the "white woman victim". What's funny is that my ex-boss was no stranger to yelling, gossiping about me, slamming mail on my desk, or hanging up on me mid sentence.

pros: Great opportunity to build your public speaking and team building skills. Learning how to facilitate meetings with other team members help show how to work with different personalities and work ethics. I learned how to listen and balance everyone’s interests. Keeping high school girls engaged for 2.5 hours was challenging, but it forced me learn how to be a more assertive and energetic speaker, which is a presentation style I now use all the time.
cons: Management can be a bit overbearing. They put pressure on girls to dedicate as much time as they can to the program. They seemed to forgot that they hired high schoolers who are active in multiple extracurricular activities. Would favor girls who made the job top priority and gave them more hours to work. It created an unhealthy competitive environment amongst colleagues.

job_title: Summer Camp Counselor in Franklin, IN
pros: It was rewarding seeing the girls find their new love for the STEM programs. The staff was really flexible and willing to help if you needed it.
cons: Training for situations regarding parents/guardians wasn't pressed as much as I wish it had.

pros: Working with the children is quite rewarding.

pros: Family oriented organization that cares about its employees and girls we serve.

pros: None. Horrible pay, bullying among staff. Racism. No support. No training.
cons:
There are many stories of racism among staff when i worked there. Nobody felt comfortable coming forward because of past experiences of not being heard. I was bullied by my coworker when first receiving the job. She made it clear that she did not think i deserved the job bc she wanted the position for her friend. She then would have daily rants in the morning about how racism did not exists. She would tell of stories of racism she heard in the news and how it was all false. every single day. I do not understand how someone with such a view point would think it was okay to work among african american children who fo and will experience racism in their life. She was then supppose to train me which she did not. Later lies were spread about me when lead to me leaving the position.

I also had many teens tell me they did not like being represented as poor, or without having a father at funsraiser to try to obtain more fiancial support. This was not the story for many teens which they feautured for the event. One teen was very distraught over this because her parents were happily married with a very loving father. The facility stereotypes their African American girls who all have different stories.

pros: You get to do really meaningful work with the community

pros: The satisfaction of knowing that while working for them you are helping change the lives of young women in your area is awesome enough, but there is more. The staff is loving and kind and really want to get to know you personally and about your life. No one working for this company is mean or vindictive. They also take volunteers for their events and around the office and such which is a great way to intern!
cons: Sadly if you work for them you don't get paid what you are worth. I worked in many different areas in the office such as IT, graphic design, labor, etc. for them and should have been making at least $15 an hour. I was being paid half that. Sadly part of the reason was I was hired through a temp agency, but it unfortunately wasn't enough to live on and I eventually had to take a higher paying job... that after three years I regretted. This is a con, surely, but after all they are a non profit agency so I took this in stride. While I was not pleased at how much I was making I do have to say I helped changed people's lives and to me personally what more could you ask for?

job_title: Teacher Assistant in Rapid City, SD
pros: things are pretty good here
cons: not very many to speak of

review_title: Girls Inc of Alameda County, CA
pros: My experience at Girls Inc was good overall. My favorite aspects of the organization included the girls I worked with, the incredible leadership of Zakiya, the freedom to basically create my own curriculum and run my classroom how I wanted, and the experience of watching the girls grow over an entire summer. I worked with the high school cohorts in grades 9-11 and from the Thrive workshops at the beginning of the summer to the Eurekathon at the end, I witnessed an amazing transformation in all of my girls. They learned valuable skills about career and college readiness, health and well-being, and more.
cons: At times, I felt I had little direction as a classroom facilitator. Granted, the whole staff received training during the first couple of days of the program in order to better understand and work with the girls however, I felt this training was really geared towards the instructors who worked with younger cohorts. In high school aged youth, you don't see the same problems and issues as you would in middle schoolers. It would have been great to get more direction on how to best work with the girls I was working with and how to best grow as an instructor. Also, I felt the staff was often very cliquey and most of the time, I did not feel like I fit in quite as much as others did.

job_title: Leadership Development Program Associate in Oakland, CA
pros: Connection to community through time at school
cons: This is technically a part time job, with part-time pay and few benefits, but the job really requires full time commitment. Program leaders are overworked and underappreciated. Managing staff is constantly saying how program leaders are "most important part" of the organization, but program leaders are the only ones without salary positions. High rate of turnover due to lack of support for those actually working in the classroom with students who are often suffering from trauma. Afterschool program leaders are treated poorly and as disposable (which they turn out to be) and there is extremely high turnover. At the end of the day, those who suffer most from this system are the students who are constantly adjusting to new teachers and feeling unloved because their teachers are constantly leaving them.

pros: This post is specifically for my experiences at Girls Inc. of Alameda County. The girls are amazing and the only reason program staff keep returning to work. We have amazing facilities for the girls (kitchen, yoga studio, fitness center) and a counseling center on site for the girls. It’s really nice to be able to refer girls immediately when they need mental health services.
cons: This post is specifically for Girls Inc. of Alameda County. Senior level management does not care about program staff. I have never had our CEO or CPO attend my program to see what I’m doing well and where I need support. Raises are never given—not even to employees who have been there 10+ years. Program staff quit on an almost yearly basis, which makes it hard to learn because everyone is new. On top of that, it’s very hard for the girls when there is so much turnover. Right now, everyone is angry and negative all the time because senior level staff aren’t acknowledging our high turnover rate. I do not recommend working here for at least 5+ years—maybe things will have gotten better.

review_title: There's the good and the bad
pros: It's a literacy based program so you get to help children progress in their literacy which is very fulfilling.  You get to help families and gain a lot of experience doing so.
cons: They don't provide enough full time positions during the school year. And the  pay/ hours isn't enough to sustain honestly.  Also, your position changes during the summer so you could be full time during the school year and then part time during the summer because positions are limited.  Lastly, People call out like crazy and then you end up with so many kids in your class from other classes. Very inconsistent. They don't have subs. By the end of each school year I would be burnt out and it's not really because of the kids, its the program and the lack of structure.

review_title: This is for Alameda county branch
pros:
Girls Inc. works really hard to help its employees grow. There are a lot of opportunities for free training, flexible schedules if you have school, and opportunities for professional development. Most of the people here are willing to help you develop a certain skill set, and will go out of their way to do so if you name it and ask for help in that area. 

You also feel great doing tangible work for the community,and you can see actual changes happen in the youth we work with. It feels good to be a part of that.
cons: The most challenging part is the pay and the hours. This is a non profit so the amount of unpaid overtime adds up (especially for summer programs) and it's all the more frustrating when the salary is low to begin with. It's easy to say you won't work over time, but next to impossible to actually do AND get your job expectations done.

review_title: Girls, Inc Community Mental Health Pioneers
pros: Girls, Inc is a non-profit organization making a difference for many young people to move beyond boundaries which otherwise leave them marginalized and disadvantaged in ability to succeed.
cons: Some of the research on which therapeutic training was based was a bit out of date, a bit rigid, and not as clearly defined or presented as possible.  For example, Girls, Inc is a leader in community mental health models and multi-cultural awareness, yet there was no instruction in social justice and restorative justice models of community mental health approaches because the agency defined itself by psychodynamic constructs.  This was not necessary.

review_title: Great part-time during school year; stressful full-time during summers
pros: It's a rewarding job where I feel like I'm contributing every day to girls' well-being. Support materials from Girls Inc. national help with lesson planning, and the executive director of our location works to find grants and raise money that allow us to serve more people. Our team of program teachers is wonderful; we are able to depend on each other for support and have fun.
cons: Because it's a non-profit, part-time pay is just minimum wage, which doesn't feel like much when we spend many hours outside of work lesson planning, preparing, and reviewing our programs. During the summer, a multiple-shift schedule means that communication doesn't work as well and contributes to stress.

job_title: Program Specialist in Red Bluff, CA
pros: A great organization helping young girls grow up to become leaders in their communities—and in the world! Best part of the job— the girls!
cons:
Northern Sacramento Valley Chapter was poorly run for a time, but seems to be getting back on track, even with a new power-hungry ED on-board. 
In my short time with the organization, I witness “3” E D’s take, and then leave, their position(s).  This occurred in less than two years time.  Also, a detriment to the organization is that they offer NO training to their Facilitators/Mentors.

review_title: Working at Girls Inc of Alameda Co allowed me to inspire girls to be Strong, Smart & Bold while I developed leadership.
pros: A mostly female environment that encourages open communication and empowering young girls and women.  An organization that values its employees through professional development, training and mentors.  Working with passionate and like-minded women to address education and social justice issues with girls of all ages.
cons: As it is a nonprofit, the salaries and positions available are limited.  It can be difficult to move up within the organization because of the limited Manager and Director positions.  The salaries are competitive with nonprofits in the area but not comparable to the cost of living in the Bay Area and the for-profit companies.

pros: Great vision, kids were amazing to work with and I really learned a lot personally, and saw the effect program had on participants.
cons: The disparity between lower level and higher level staff was extreme and there was not much respect for program leaders, who so most of the work. Culture of passive aggressiveness and cattiness, hard to move up because it was more of a “who you know” atmosphere. Some anti-black microaggressions sadly. Some of the higher ups did not seem to be there for the right reasons

pros: Great relationships with direct staff, positive environment. A wonderful opportunity to provide intentional and compensatory programming to young girls who need the support.  This is fulfilling work with a flexible schedule.  Paid well in comparison to similar positions in other orgs, however compensation is below level for the caliber of work expected.
cons:
VERY few opportunities for: advancement, networking between direct staff and corporate staff, professional development (unless it directly relates to improved job functions)
Not paid well, amount of flexibility required makes it difficult to sustain additional employment
Expectations of the role do not match time given to complete.
We are inspiring girls to be strong smart & bold, but the org is not doing the same for its employees.

pros: I worked here for just under a year and I truly loved and enjoyed my time at Girls Inc. My center was filled with kind, passionate, and engaging people and I felt as though I learned so much in so little time, which is good, because training was very minimal and I had no prior experience teaching. This was an engaging, rewarding, and fun job that I loved doing.
cons: Unfortunately, the pay is really low. This leads to some resentment from the staff, which is understandable but also frustrating. It also leads to a ton of turnover, which is a huge downside.

pros: Great mission and coworkers. Programs create positive outcomes. Opportunity to make a differences in students lives. Opportunity to learn and grow.
cons: Extremely heavy workload. Asked to do more then can be accomplished in 26 hours. Prep time continually cut into with training. Almost zero prep time during minimum weeks. Pay not in line with what you are being asked to do/accomplish. Those lacking teaching backgrounds are put into the classroom with very little training to prepare them to meet expectations.

review_title: Great mission for the company. Empowering young women to be, "strong, smart and bold."
job_title: Program Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Fulfilling, but still draining at times. Seeing the impact you have on your students is definitely rewarding. Creating future leaders. PTO, 403 B plan and benefits for a part time job.
cons: They overwork and underpay you. What is a part time job definitely feels full time. Having to do extra administrative work and not getting compensated as you should for it. Being in an all female environment which can be catty at times.

pros: Hours are flexible, you are truly given the space to be creative with the classes that you build, great opportunity to affect change in the lives of the girls you encounter
cons: Sometimes budget can restrict creativity, often having to do more work than you are truly being compensated for, PT staff get barely any benefits and

pros: Great work atmosphere, everyone was always really helpful and friendly. They were moving offices while I worked there and everyone was always talking about it.
cons: No parking at the newer offices. Sometimes leadership failed to help deal with situations effectively. Working with the girls sometimes proved to be hard, as their home lives were not always great and it spilled over into their school lives.

review_title: Rewarding but challenging work with opportunity to see results.
pros: Direct impact on lives of individuals.  Colleagues are like-minded, positive, and dedicated. The curriculum written at the national level is based on research and is timely.
cons: Some teens are difficult to work with. Sometimes programming is driven by grant requirements or mandates from National office, preventing us from adapting to local needs.Theres a fair amount of turnover, which affects the continuity of relationships with partner sites and results in loss of experienced instructors.

pros: Very strong commitment to the mission statement. Draws in experienced individuals. Serves many families throughout the age spectrum 6-18. Strong focus on intentional and compensatory activities as well as high school graduation and attending college. The passion is clearly there and if this is the right fit for you, there is the potential to work in many areas of direct service in the agency. Collaboration with many other agencies and companies with a new Downtown Oakland location. Media attention, exposure and branding increasingly present in the community.
cons: Senior leadership is often out of touch with what group leaders and coordinators need at the program level. Compensation for direct service staff is low for what is expected of them, without pay increases over many years of service. Promotion and other opportunities seem to be saved for certain people and not always accessible to others. There is a strong sensitivity when staff speak up and provide constructive criticism, ideas, and requests for change. It is not always received well, but that varies. The culture of the agency is not one that promotes work-life balance, although certain managers may emphasize it more to their team. Budget is large but program budgets stay the same, even when trying to expand programming. It takes a great deal of advocating to get what you and our program need to get to the next level. Evaluation is inconsistent at best but they are working on improving the system. New building layout does not currently maximize program space for girls. The organization has been around for well over 50 years and many traditions are set in senior management's minds although they strive to have a culture of learning. It's a challenge to bring newness to the agency and can take a long time. It is a challenge to provide equal amounts of accessibility and learning for donors and families; they are two completely different groups and they need to be catered to equally in terms of information and marketing.

pros:
- Rewarding experience: Seeing the young girls be so excited during program, watching them grow, and being a part of their educational experience was one of the most rewarding experiences I've had

- Culturally/Politically aware: Girls Inc. was very much aligned with my beliefs, and are constantly fighting for the rights of those who are marginalized. It felt great to work in an environment that I supported. 

-Women/POC Staff: There are a lot of women and people of color that work at Girls Inc. Their politics are prioritized and valued. 

- Training: Girls Inc. has a very solid training program. It can be redundant at times, but lays the groundwork for those who are interested in working in education. You basically learn how to be a certified teacher, without getting certified. 

- Tokens of appreciation: Girls Inc. gives its employees appreciation lunches, and small kits every now and then to show appreciation.
cons:
- Benefits: poor benefits & healthcare package, especially with the already relatively low pay. 

- Short hours: You are expected to do the job of a certified teacher, but are not allotted the hours to prepare. You will find yourself working outside of the classroom to catch up to the work, or if you fall behind you will notice it getting way harder to manage the kids. 

- Low retention, not much validation from higher-ups: While the higher ups will constantly tell you that you have "the most important job" at the agency, you will not be treated like so. You will often be subtly asked to work over hours without being able to put these hours on your time sheet. You will not be given long-term validation by management, because they are too busy and overworked themselves. You might become emotionally burnt out by the work. 

No Professional Development: You will not be able to advance to a different position unless you first work as a program leader for years. This is a very difficult thing to do, because of how emotionally and physically draining the job can be.

pros: You get to work with kids, have fun, help them learn things we may take for granted but that many kids are not being taught. You get a combination of office work and "field work" at the school sites.
cons: You work long hours but they do not pay over-time. Staff gets too personal yet ultimately only cares about the participants, donors and board members; employees don't matter. They can also cut your hours without warning.

pros: Very rewarding job working as an after school teacher with girl elementary aged girls, very empowering working with women, great training, non-profit has high standards for their employees so you are always challenged intellectually with also the freedom to be creative (if you are responsible for designing curriculum, I don't know about the other positions), a great place to work!
cons: There is are a lot of internal politics involved with working for the organization, which I think is true with many non-profits.

pros: Girls Inc. Is a very fun loving place to work. If you have the want and desire to want to inspire girls to be strong,smart,and bold than this is definitely the organization to work for. The staff all seem to add a different taste of personality and it feels like home away from home.
cons: Its non profit so you won't get rich working there. Your heart definitely had to be in the job and you need to believe in the mission.

pros:
Girls Inc. is an amazing company to work for. Working there was one of the best experiences and has really shaped me as a person.

- Amazing staff
- The girls are to learn and are enthusiastic about what they are learning
cons: I do not think I have any downsides to working at Girls Inc. The pay is not great because it is a nonprofit but the environment and people you get to work with are well worth it.

review_title: Volunteer as a girls guide at elementary school
pros: The organization itself has heart and very admirable goals. Training and general course structure is very well organized and based in actual research. The people who work there are genuine and really seem to believe in the work they do.
cons: Lovely ideas, poor execution. The materials simply are not age-specific enough to be accurately and effectively taught. Although this is partly due to specific schools, teachers and volunteers are thrown into a classroom setting with a binder and little guidance.

review_title: Good for starting out in nonprofits
pros:
This is for the Alameda County affiliate.

Great work with the community and truly tried to provide holistic support to employees.
cons: This nonprofit is the definition of the white savior complex. Administrative and leaders were predominantly white, and direct service employees were all Black and brown. They don't give salary raises. I knew one person who had worked there for almost 10 years without a salary raise which feels unheard of in the Bay Area.

review_title: Although stressful at times it is also extremely rewarding
pros: Working with kids can be extremely rewarding and insightful. You are reminded every day why you work for this organization and why what you do is extremely vital. It's just a place with such great energy !
cons: Promotions from within were rare for individuals in lower level positions.

pros: It's a good place to gain experience in leadership and youth programs with minimal supervision. Opportunities for additional experience in administration, finance, fundraising may be availble as well. Experience gained here can lead to opportunities in other fields.
cons: Being a non-profit, salary is low and workload is high. Professional growth and/or continuing education is often discouraged because turnover is already high. Limited opportunities above entry level.

review_title: A diservice to employees' professional development
pros: You have the opportunity to meet some inspiring women who initially come into the organization embodying the Girls Inc. mission.
cons:
No professional growth
Prone to gossip
Unprofessional
No Human Resources Department and clear set policies
NO accountability for senior level and mid-level employees
You will feel like an at-will employee
Benefits package lacks vision, dental, and retirement plan
Mismanagement of funds

pros: Very caring community that aims to positively grow its team members as well as the young girls who attend after-school programs.
cons: I would only use this as a part time job. It is great for college students needing to work after class or in the summer, but it does not pay hardly well enough to be a full time position r career.

pros:
-The staff are extremely welcoming and camaraderie is a strong part of their culture.
-It's obvious that the people working there truly care about the mission of Girls Inc, which makes it a very fulfilling & inspiring place to work.
-Job training was very thorough so that you feel fully prepared
cons: -Working with children can be tiring, but that is the nature of the job if you take a position that involves that.

pros: Girls Inc. has a great mission and people to work with. Work is challenging and plenty of opportunity to reach for stretch goals.
cons: Goals and objectives do not necessarily align with employee vision for career advancement. Stretch goals are often imposed that are not achievable.

job_title: Teen Program Facilitator in Costa Mesa, CA
pros: Webinars and seminars are covered. Tools to keep learning are available and paid for when you have the time to complete them. Reputable organization, offers great connections to the orange county education system. Opportunities to develop projects with guidance of exceptional coordinators.
cons: Challenging to promote sustainability missions in curriculum with a high turn over. Projects change very quickly.

pros: The vision is empowering. As I worked with the participants I really grew as a person and made a lifetime of memories. I miss my students so much and still stay in contact with them. Great starting hourly rate. Avg. 20-30 hours a week depending on afterschool schedule. You are able to exercise your creativity and do what you love.
cons: Unorganized. Full-time work for part time pay.

review_title: Review of Girls Inc. of NYC
pros: A lot of opportunity to directly impact the lives of young girls. Everyone is dedicated to the mission and does their best to meet the needs of the young people. They want their employees to be happy and healthy.
cons: Somewhat disorganized, but working to rectify this. Opportunities for advancement from part time to full time are rare and only happen once per year.

pros: The opportunity to work with all kinds of girls who are discovering their potential is exciting. The program's truly are research based and thoroughly vetted, evaluated.
cons: Usual nonprofit stuff; limited resources and grant funded programs ending when the funds run out. It was disappointing to get attached and then have to leave because of funding.

review_title: My experience working at Girls Inc
pros: Their values and worth ethic are amaizing. I enjoyed the environment and the positive encouragement that I received from coordinators and directos, as well as managers.
cons: I wish they could work with us Program leaders in getting some type of teaching license, since a lot that we do at the job is teach!

review_title: Great place to work with girls
pros: If you like working with children and believe that there is a serious need for female empowerment then you should join this organization.
cons: There was very little training and compensation for extra time and resources is not available.

pros: Working for Girls Inc. has been the most amazing experience. Coworkers are kind, motivated, and always willing to help. Working with girls all across Orange County has been a blessing, as you get to help others and change lives on a daily basis.
cons: There are no real cons here.

review_title: Fun Job, lots of energy needed
job_title: Youth Program Faciltator in Santa Barbara, CA
pros: Great part-time job, especially for the summer. Fun co-workers, diverse working community, lots of opportunity to learn
cons: Can be very fast-paced and not always time to get up to speed on how to do certain tasks in the classroom, need to spend time outside work building your teaching skills

pros: The environment is very open, flexible and progressive.
cons: For being an organization that's meant to empower women and girls of color, they lack diversity as the chain of command goes up.

pros: If you're interested in working with kids from diverse backgrounds, this is a good place to be. There is a lot of creative license around developing content for the kids.
cons: Not enough support for staff, not enough trauma-informed training or crisis de-escalation skill building

job_title: Project Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: The people at Girls Inc. were amazing. Very respectful and understanding of other's individuality.
cons: Limited growth capabilities because of a lack of positions available.

job_title: STEM Camp Facilitator in Austin, TX
pros: Amazing work environment, friendly, energetic, upbeat, encouraging. Girls are wonderful to work with, really enjoyed my time.
cons: It does require constant energy, which can be rough day after day. Also, fair amount of variation from task to task, working in different areas can be dramatically different.

job_title: Marketing Associate in New York, NY
pros: Summer hours and relaxed atmosphere in terms of dress code.
cons: Supportive environment with people who are on your level. Upper management is snarky and uninformed. No room for growth.

pros: This is a great mission-based organization with research-informed programs and initiatives.
